p: India is an especially useful context for examining climate injustice since a significant increase in mean temperature between 1986 and 2015 has been recorded [11] (p. 22). Furthermore, several climate models project that heatwaves in India will occur earlier in the year, last longer, and increase in both frequency and intensity [12,13,14,15,16]. While prolonged exposure to temperatures above 35 °C has the potential to exceed human adaptive capacity, the highest temperatures during heatwaves in India are likely to go well beyond this and reach around 50 °C [16]. As population and built-up surface continue to expand in major urban areas in India [17,18], it becomes imperative to analyze whether socially vulnerable populations reside in areas exposed to higher levels of heat.
